name: Impactor-2025
description: A hypothetical near-Earth asteroid impact scenario demonstrating the Defend Earth simulation system

timeline.description: Near-Earth asteroid 2025-IMP detected by ground-based telescopes. Initial orbital calculations show potential Earth impact trajectory.
Detailed analysis confirms impact probability of 85%. Asteroid diameter estimated at 500m, mass approximately 200 million tons.
Kinetic impactor spacecraft launched to intercept asteroid. Mission designed to apply 0.1 m/s delta-v 90 days before impact.
Asteroid approaches Earth, deflection mission in final phase. Ground-based tracking shows successful trajectory modification.
Kinetic impactor successfully deflects asteroid. Miss distance increased from 0km to 15,000km. Earth impact avoided.
Post-deflection analysis confirms successful mission. Asteroid continues on modified orbit, no longer a threat to Earth.

educational_notes: This scenario demonstrates the importance of early detection and deflection capabilities for planetary defense.
The kinetic impactor method is one of the most feasible deflection strategies, requiring years of lead time.
Success depends on precise targeting, sufficient impactor mass, and accurate orbital predictions.
Real deflection missions would require international cooperation and significant resources.
The 0.1 m/s delta-v applied 90 days before impact is sufficient to change the miss distance by thousands of kilometers.
This simulation uses simplified physics models; real deflection missions would require more complex calculations.
